EXPERIMENT.TITLE: MiSeq of DNA from virus particles: Female room 3 HVAC filter

DESIGN.DESIGN_DESCRIPTION: Virus particles were dislodged from HVAC filters located in double-occupancy university dormitory rooms through sonication. Virus particles were then purified from cellular debris and free nucleic acids through filtration and nuclease treatment. Viral DNA was extracted with the MinElute Virus Spin kit (Qiagen) and sheared using a Covaris instrument. NGS libraries were then prepared using the Accel-NGS 1S Plus DNA Library Kit for Illumina Platforms (Swift Biosciences) and pair-end sequenced on a MiSeq platform.

DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_ABSTRACT: Diverse microbial communities inhabit human-occupied buildings and circulate in indoor air; however, little is known about viral diversity in these environments. Here we investigated DNA and RNA viruses circulating in the air of university dormitory rooms (n = 12) by analyzing dust accumulated over a one-year period on heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) filters through viral metagenomics. This study significantly expands the known airborne viral diversity found indoors, enabling the design of sensitive and quantitative assays to further investigate specific viruses of interest.

SAMPLE.DESCRIPTION: DNA viral metagenome from dust accumulated on HVAC filters over a one-year period

SAMPLE.TITLE: M1_DNA
SAMPLE.DESCRIPTION: DNA viral metagenome from dust accumulated on HVAC filters over a one-year period

EXPERIMENT.TITLE: MiSeq of DNA from negative control

DESIGN.DESIGN_DESCRIPTION: Suspension medium (SM) buffer alone was processed through sonication and viral purification methods as a negative control. DNA was extracted with the MinElute Virus Spin kit (Qiagen) and sheared using a Covaris instrument. NGS libraries were then prepared using the Accel-NGS 1S Plus DNA Library Kit for Illumina Platforms (Swift Biosciences) and pair-end sequenced on a MiSeq platform.

DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_ABSTRACT: Diverse microbial communities inhabit human-occupied buildings and circulate in indoor air; however, little is known about viral diversity in these environments. Here we investigated DNA and RNA viruses circulating in the air of university dormitory rooms (n = 12) by analyzing dust accumulated over a one-year period on heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) filters through viral metagenomics. This study significantly expands the known airborne viral diversity found indoors, enabling the design of sensitive and quantitative assays to further investigate specific viruses of interest.

SAMPLE.TITLE: NegativeControl_DNA
SAMPLE.DESCRIPTION: DNA viral metagenome from dust accumulated on HVAC filters over a one-year period

EXPERIMENT.TITLE: MiSeq of cDNA from virus particles: Male room 6 HVAC filter

DESIGN.DESIGN_DESCRIPTION: Virus particles were dislodged from HVAC filters located in double-occupancy university dormitory rooms through sonication. Virus particles were then purified from cellular debris and free nucleic acids through filtration and nuclease treatment. Viral RNA was extracted with the RNeasy kit (Qiagen) and reverse-transcribed using the SuperScript III First Strand Synthesis System (Invitrogen) with random hexamers. Second-strand synthesis was performed on the resulting cDNA using the Klenow Fragment DNA polymerase (New England Biolabs) and the resulting products were cleaned using the AMPure XP Purification system. Double-stranded cDNA was then sheared using a Covaris instrument. NGS libraries were prepared using the Accel-NGS 1S Plus DNA Library Kit for Illumina Platforms (Swift Biosciences) and pair-end sequenced on a MiSeq platform.

DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_ABSTRACT: Diverse microbial communities inhabit human-occupied buildings and circulate in indoor air; however, little is known about viral diversity in these environments. Here we investigated DNA and RNA viruses circulating in the air of university dormitory rooms (n = 12) by analyzing dust accumulated over a one-year period on heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) filters through viral metagenomics. This study significantly expands the known airborne viral diversity found indoors, enabling the design of sensitive and quantitative assays to further investigate specific viruses of interest.

DESIGN.DESIGN_DESCRIPTION: Virus particles were dislodged from HVAC filters located in double-occupancy university dormitory rooms through sonication. Virus particles were then purified from cellular debris and free nucleic acids through filtration and nuclease treatment. Viral RNA was extracted with the RNeasy kit (Qiagen) and reverse-transcribed using the SuperScript III First Strand Synthesis System (Invitrogen) with random hexamers. Second-strand synthesis was performed on the resulting cDNA using the Klenow Fragment DNA polymerase (New England Biolabs) and the resulting products were cleaned using the AMPure XP Purification system. Double-stranded cDNA was then sheared using a Covaris instrument. NGS libraries were prepared using the Accel-NGS 1S Plus DNA Library Kit for Illumina Platforms (Swift Biosciences) and pair-end sequenced on a MiSeq platform.

DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_ABSTRACT: Diverse microbial communities inhabit human-occupied buildings and circulate in indoor air; however, little is known about viral diversity in these environments. Here we investigated DNA and RNA viruses circulating in the air of university dormitory rooms (n = 12) by analyzing dust accumulated over a one-year period on heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) filters through viral metagenomics. This study significantly expands the known airborne viral diversity found indoors, enabling the design of sensitive and quantitative assays to further investigate specific viruses of interest.

SAMPLE.TITLE: M4_RNA
SAMPLE.DESCRIPTION: RNA viral metagenome from dust accumulated on HVAC filters over a one-year period

EXPERIMENT.TITLE: MiSeq of cDNA from virus particles: Female room 2 HVAC filter
